content.description: Climb the blocky ramp to the left of the obvious crack, using said crack for pro.  At the roof/ledge, either go straight up (5.7) through a shallow left-facing dihedral, OR go left along the ledge and then back right along the huge ramp to the top.
content.protection: Gear to 2"  There are two sets of chains: one set is up on top of the cliff; the other set is lower on the wall just a couple moves above the roof/ledge.
content.location: Right of the Open Book is a lightning bolt crack that goes up to a large horizontal roof/ledge feature.  It should be obvious.

content.description: Climb straight up the face and traverse left (the crus) to a "shark tooth" like feature

This route is on the rock to the far left of the lower ledge. I believe it is the only bolted route on this particular rock.

The crux is definitely at the top.

5 bolts to HA.

Climb up the obvious right-facing corner in the center of the cliff through some blocky overhangs.

Pretty cool moves and decent protection.  Short.
content.protection: Gear to 2".  Two bolts with rap rings at the top.
content.location: Obvious open book in the center of the cliff.

content.description: This great toprope climbs the thin face to the right of Open Book (using the same anchors).  The crux is down low, but fun sequences continue to the top.
content.protection: TR or solo.  Chains at the top.
content.location: Look for the U-shaped rail on the face to the right of Open Book.  The route climbs through this.

content.description: The Climber's Guide to North Idaho gives this climb an 5.11a rating which is very soft in my opinion.  This route is just left of McJugs.  It actually meets up with McJugs after at the 3rd bolt.  Climb up the thin face to the namesake ledge.  Mantle over ledge and up thin face to anchors above.
content.location: On the right end of Lower Ledge Wall near Great Controversy.  One route to the left of McJugs.

content.description: This climb starts at the base of the arete for Great Controversy.  Climb up and left following the sloping ramp.  Climbing isn't too hard but it does feel a little awkward.  Mantle the famous ledge and then thin climbing leads to anchors.
content.location: Right end of Lower Ledge Wall.  One route to the left of Great Controversy (starts at pretty much the same place).

content.description:
This is a pumpy endeavor after the first bolt. It starts in the crack system below, but the crux is pulling your butt over the obvious roof. =) This involves a sweet heelhook and a series of crimps once over the top.

One note: If you are attempting to toprope this route, be careful of your rope snagging on the third bolt as you pull over the roof!
content.location: The is the first route you encounter as you head down the staircase, and is the southmost route at the Lower Ledge Wall. Just think, "where is the overhang that will cause my feet to fly into mid-air?"  =)

content.description: The grantite on this route is beautiful, the sequence is fun and it is well protected. This is definitely one of my favorite warm up routes on the Ledge Wall. Don't miss this climb! (This would also make a good first lead for a competant climber, all of the holds to clip off of are bomber.)

Rap from the Tree Route staples and hang Top Rope Draws on the chains that are just above the tree stump, about 30 feet down from the top.  Pleasant face climbing underneath the tree keeping left of the edge of the Tree Crack Route
Just to the right of Rock Whoopi (5.7) lots of big features. This route is also a fun top rope. The anchors can be reached easily by going up the trail to the right of the route.

climbs.name: Darcy's Law aka Rock of Ages

content.description:
This is the crack that coincides with the start of The Great Controversy. The initial starting position for the 2 routes is the same.

Start in under the alcove as for The Great Controversy but follow the overhanging hand crack that widens gradually to #5 and #6 BD size through a short horizontal roof section. Once the horizontal section is surmounted, easier climbing leads to the top.
content.protection:
Hand size gear protects this climb well with mandatory 5"-6" gear to keep you off the ground at the horizontal section. The hardest parts of the climb would be close to the ground(!) in the event of a fall so bring an attentive belay.

There are currently no top anchors (Sept 2020) set for this route but you can rig a top anchor off the neighboring climbs if they are unoccupied. It would require longer than standard anchor material to do so. 5"-6" gear anchor also possible. The walk-off and walk-on to top of the crag is just at the top of the staircase.
content.location: This will be the first route you encounter coming down the staircase approach to the lower ledge area. It is the farthest route to the right on lower ledge area wall.

content.description: A delicately thin slab requiring precision footwork and proper breath holding technique.
Climbs directl up the face to the tip of a left pointing roof
content.location: 2 routes to the right of Tree Crack

content.description: A very good first lead for a strong top roper. Also a fun warm up, the crux is pretty much the first 2 moves, the rest of it is a cake walk.
content.protection: Bring 9 draws with you, 7 bolts and two for the top.
content.location: Located on the far left of the Ledge Wall.
